Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: employment refers to any employment of the claimant within their qualifying period or their benefit period;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: loss of employment includes a suspension from employment, but does not include loss of, or suspension from, employment on account of membership in, or lawful activity connected with, an association, organization or union of workers;

Paragraph.Label: (b.1)
Paragraph.Text: voluntarily leaving an employment includes

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the refusal of employment offered as an alternative to an anticipated loss of employment, in which case the voluntary leaving occurs when the loss of employment occurs,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the refusal to resume an employment, in which case the voluntary leaving occurs when the employment is supposed to be resumed, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the refusal to continue in an employment after the work, undertaking or business of the employer is transferred to another employer, in which case the voluntary leaving occurs when the work, undertaking or business is transferred; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: just cause for voluntarily leaving an employment or taking leave from an employment exists if the claimant had no reasonable alternative to leaving or taking leave, having regard to all the circumstances, including any of the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: sexual or other harassment,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: obligation to accompany a spouse, common-law partner or dependent child to another residence,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: discrimination on a prohibited ground of discrimination within the meaning of the Canadian Human Rights Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: working conditions that constitute a danger to health or safety,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: obligation to care for a child or a member of the immediate family,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: reasonable assurance of another employment in the immediate future,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: significant modification of terms and conditions respecting wages or salary,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: excessive overtime work or refusal to pay for overtime work,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: significant changes in work duties,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: antagonism with a supervisor if the claimant is not primarily responsible for the antagonism,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: practices of an employer that are contrary to law,

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: discrimination with regard to employment because of membership in an association, organization or union of workers,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiii)
Subparagraph.Text: undue pressure by an employer on the claimant to leave their employment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xiv)
Subparagraph.Text: any other reasonable circumstances that are prescribed.

Section.MarginalNote: Disqualification — misconduct or leaving without just cause

Subsection.Text: A claimant is disqualified from receiving any benefits if the claimant lost any employment because of their misconduct or voluntarily left any employment without just cause, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant has, since losing or leaving the employment, been employed in insurable employment for the number of hours required by section 7 or 7.1 to qualify to receive benefits; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant is disentitled under sections 31 to 33 in relation to the employment.

Subsection.Text: The disqualification is for each week of the claimant’s benefit period following the waiting period and, for greater certainty, the length of the disqualification is not affected by any subsequent loss of employment by the claimant during the benefit period.

If the event giving rise to the disqualification occurs during a benefit period of the claimant, the disqualification does not include any week in that benefit period before the week in which the event occurs.
Notwithstanding subsection (6), the disqualification is suspended during any week for which the claimant is otherwise entitled to special benefits.

If a claimant who has lost or left an employment as described in subsection (1) makes an initial claim for benefits, the following hours may not be used to qualify under section 7 or 7.1 to receive benefits:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: hours of insurable employment from that or any other employment before the employment was lost or left; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: hours of insurable employment in any employment that the claimant subsequently loses or leaves, as described in subsection (1).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Restriction on number of weeks and rate of benefits
Subsection.Text: No hours of insurable employment in any employment that a claimant loses or leaves, as described in subsection (1), may be used for the purpose of determining the maximum number of weeks of benefits under subsection 12(2) or the claimant’s rate of weekly benefits under section 14.

For greater certainty, but subject to paragraph (1)(a), a claimant may be disqualified under subsection (1) even if the claimant’s last employment before their claim for benefits was not lost or left as described in that subsection and regardless of whether their claim is an initial claim for benefits.

Section.Text: A claimant who is suspended from their employment because of their misconduct is not entitled to receive benefits until

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the period of suspension expires;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant loses or voluntarily leaves the employment; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant, after the beginning of the period of suspension, accumulates with another employer the number of hours of insurable employment required by section 7 or 7.1 to qualify to receive benefits.

Section.MarginalNote: Disentitlement — period of leave without just cause

Subsection.Text: A claimant who voluntarily takes a period of leave from their employment without just cause is not entitled to receive benefits if, before or after the beginning of the period of leave,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the period of leave was authorized by the employer; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant and the employer agreed as to the day on which the claimant would resume employment.

Subsection.Text: The disentitlement lasts until the claimant

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: resumes the employment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: loses or voluntarily leaves the employment; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: after the beginning of the period of leave, accumulates with another employer the number of hours of insurable employment required by section 7 or 7.1 to qualify to receive benefits.

Subsection.Text: A claimant is not entitled to receive benefits if the claimant loses an employment because of their misconduct or voluntarily leaves without just cause within three weeks before

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the expiration of a term of employment, in the case of employment for a set term; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the claimant is to be laid off according to a notice already given by the employer to the claimant.

Subsection.Text: The disentitlement lasts until the expiration of the term of employment or the day on which the claimant was to be laid off.

Section.Text: A disentitlement under sections 31 to 33 is suspended during any week for which the claimant is otherwise entitled to special benefits.

Notwithstanding anything in this Part, no claimant is disqualified or disentitled under sections 30 to 33 from receiving benefits only because the claimant left or refused to accept employment if, by remaining in or accepting the employment, the claimant would lose the right

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to become or refrain from becoming a member of an association, organization or union of workers; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to continue to be a member and to observe the lawful rules of an association, organization or union of workers.

Subsection.Text: Subject to the regulations, if a claimant loses an employment, or is unable to resume an employment, because of a work stoppage attributable to a labour dispute at the factory, workshop or other premises at which the claimant was employed, the claimant is not entitled to receive benefits until the earlier of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the end of the work stoppage, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the claimant becomes regularly engaged elsewhere in insurable employment.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations for determining the number of days of disentitlement in a week of a claimant who loses a part-time employment or is unable to resume a part-time employment because of the reason mentioned in subsection (1).
A disentitlement under this section is suspended during any period for which the claimant

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establishes that the claimant is otherwise entitled to special benefits or benefits by virtue of section 25; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: establishes, in such manner as the Commission may direct, that before the work stoppage, the claimant had anticipated being absent from their employment because of any reason entitling them to those benefits and had begun making arrangements in relation to the absence.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply if a claimant proves that the claimant is not participating in, financing or directly interested in the labour dispute that caused the stoppage of work.

If separate branches of work that are commonly carried on as separate businesses in separate premises are carried on in separate departments on the same premises, each department is, for the purpose of this section, a separate factory or workshop.

Section.MarginalNote: Prison inmates and persons outside Canada
Section.Text: Except as may otherwise be prescribed, a claimant is not entitled to receive benefits for any period during which the claimant

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is an inmate of a prison or similar institution; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is not in Canada.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may impose on a claimant, or any other person acting for a claimant, a penalty for each of the following acts or omissions if the Commission becomes aware of facts that in its opinion establish that the claimant or other person has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a claim for benefits, made a representation that the claimant or other person knew was false or misleading;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: being required under this Act or the regulations to provide information, provided information or made a representation that the claimant or other person knew was false or misleading;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: knowingly failed to declare to the Commission all or some of the claimant’s earnings for a period determined under the regulations for which the claimant claimed benefits;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: made a claim or declaration that the claimant or other person knew was false or misleading because of the non-disclosure of facts;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: being the payee of a special warrant, knowingly negotiated or attempted to negotiate it for benefits to which the claimant was not entitled;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: knowingly failed to return a special warrant or the amount of the warrant or any excess amount, as required by section 44;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: imported or exported a document issued by the Commission, or had it imported or exported, for the purpose of defrauding or deceiving the Commission; or

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: participated in, assented to or acquiesced in an act or omission mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (g).

Subsection.Text: The Commission may set the amount of the penalty for each act or omission at not more than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: three times the claimant’s rate of weekly benefits;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the penalty is imposed under paragraph (1)(c),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: three times the amount of the deduction from the claimant’s benefits under subsection 19(3), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: three times the benefits that would have been paid to the claimant for the period mentioned in that paragraph if the deduction had not been made under subsection 19(3) or the claimant had not been disentitled or disqualified from receiving benefits; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: three times the maximum rate of weekly benefits in effect when the act or omission occurred, if no benefit period was established.

Subsection.Text: For greater certainty, weeks of regular benefits that are repaid as a result of an act or omission mentioned in subsection (1) are deemed to be weeks of regular benefits paid for the purposes of the application of subsection 145(2).

The Commission may impose on an employer, or any other person acting for an employer or pretending to be or act for an employer, a penalty for each of the following acts if the Commission becomes aware of facts that in its opinion establish that the employer or other person has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: made, in relation to any matter arising under this Act, a representation that the employer or other person knew was false or misleading;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: being required under this Act or the regulations to provide information, provided information or made a representation that the employer or other person knew was false or misleading;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to any matter arising under this Act, made a declaration that the employer or other person knew was false or misleading because of the non-disclosure of facts;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: imported or exported a document issued by the Commission, or had it imported or exported, for the purpose of defrauding or deceiving the Commission; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: participated in, assented to or acquiesced in an act mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d).

Subsection.Text: The Commission may set the amount of the penalty for each act at not more than nine times the maximum rate of weekly benefits in effect when the penalty is imposed.

If the Commission becomes aware of facts that in its opinion establish that a corporation has committed an act described in subsection (1) and that any officer, director or agent of the corporation has directed, authorized, assented to, acquiesced in or participated in the act, the Commission may impose a penalty on the officer, director or agent, whether or not a penalty has been imposed on the corporation.

Notwithstanding subsection (2), if the act involves the provision of information about any matter on which the fulfilment of conditions for the qualification and entitlement for receiving or continuing to receive benefits depends, the Commission may set the amount of the penalty at not more than the greater of

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amount of the penalty imposed under section 38 on any person who made a claim for benefits based on the information provided.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsection (2), the Commission may set the amount of the penalty at an amount required or authorized by the regulations if the act is a major contravention, as defined under the regulations.

Section.Text: A penalty shall not be imposed under section 38 or 39 if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a prosecution for the act or omission has been initiated against the employee, employer or other person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 36 months have passed since the day on which the act or omission occurred.

Section.Text: The Commission may rescind the imposition of a penalty under section 38 or 39, or reduce the penalty, on the presentation of new facts or on being satisfied that the penalty was imposed without knowledge of, or on the basis of a mistake as to, some material fact.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may issue a warning instead of setting the amount of a penalty for an act or omission under subsection 38(2) or 39(2).
Notwithstanding paragraph 40(b), a warning may be issued within 72 months after the day on which the act or omission occurred.

Heading.TitleText: Non-assignment of Benefits and Liability to Return Benefits and Pay Penalties

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), benefits are not capable of being assigned, charged, attached, anticipated or given as security and any transaction appearing to do so is void.

Any amounts payable under this Act by any person and required to be credited to the Employment Insurance Operating Account may be recovered out of any benefits payable to that person, without affecting any other mode of recovery.

If the Government of Canada, a provincial or municipal government or any other prescribed authority pays a person an advance or assistance or a welfare payment for a week that would not be paid if unemployment benefits were paid for that week, and unemployment benefits subsequently become payable to that person for that week, the Commission may, subject to the regulations, deduct from those or any subsequent benefits and pay to the government or the prescribed authority an amount equal to the amount of the advance, assistance or welfare payment paid, if the person had, on or before receiving the advance, assistance or welfare payment, consented to the deduction and payment by the Commission.

Section.Text: A claimant is liable to repay an amount paid by the Commission to the claimant as benefits

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for any period for which the claimant is disqualified; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to which the claimant is not entitled.

Section.Text: A person who has received or obtained a benefit payment to which the person is disentitled, or a benefit payment in excess of the amount to which the person is entitled, shall without delay return the amount, the excess amount or the special warrant for payment of the amount, as the case may be.

If a claimant receives benefits for a period and, under a labour arbitration award or court judgment, or for any other reason, an employer, a trustee in bankruptcy or any other person subsequently becomes liable to pay earnings, including damages for wrongful dismissal or proceeds realized from the property of a bankrupt, to the claimant for the same period and pays the earnings, the claimant shall pay to the Receiver General as repayment of an overpayment of benefits an amount equal to the benefits that would not have been paid if the earnings had been paid or payable at the time the benefits were paid.

Section.MarginalNote: Return of benefits by employer or other person

Subsection.Text: If under a labour arbitration award or court judgment, or for any other reason, an employer, a trustee in bankruptcy or any other person becomes liable to pay earnings, including damages for wrongful dismissal or proceeds realized from the property of a bankrupt, to a claimant for a period and has reason to believe that benefits have been paid to the claimant for that period, the employer or other person shall ascertain whether an amount would be repayable under section 45 if the earnings were paid to the claimant and if so shall deduct the amount from the earnings payable to the claimant and remit it to the Receiver General as repayment of an overpayment of benefits.

If a claimant receives benefits for a period and under a labour arbitration award or court judgment, or for any other reason, the liability of an employer to pay the claimant earnings, including damages for wrongful dismissal, for the same period is or was reduced by the amount of the benefits or by a portion of them, the employer shall remit the amount or portion to the Receiver General as repayment of an overpayment of benefits.

Section.Text: No amount is payable under section 45, or deductible under subsection 46(1), as a repayment of an overpayment of benefits if more than 36 months have elapsed since the lay-off or separation from the employment in relation to which the earnings are paid or payable and, in the opinion of the Commission, the administrative costs of determining the repayment would likely equal or exceed the amount of the repayment.

Section.MarginalNote: Liability of directors to pay penalties

Subsection.Text: If a penalty is imposed on a corporation under section 38 or 39 for an act or omission, the directors of the corporation at the time of the act or omission are, subject to subsections (2) to (7), jointly and severally, or solidarily, liable, together with the corporation, to pay the amount of the penalty.
A director is not liable unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate for the amount of the corporation’s liability for the penalty has been registered in the Federal Court under section 126 and execution for that amount has been returned unsatisfied in whole or in part;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the corporation has commenced liquidation or dissolution proceedings or has been dissolved and a claim for the amount of its liability has been proved within six months after the date of commencement of the proceedings or the date of the dissolution, whichever is earlier; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the corporation has made an assignment or a bankruptcy order has been made against it under the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act and a claim for the amount of its liability has been proved within six months after the date of the assignment or bankruptcy order.

Subsection.Text: A director is not liable if the director exercised the degree of care, diligence and skill that a reasonably prudent person would have exercised in comparable circumstances to prevent the act or omission for which the penalty is imposed.
No action or proceedings to recover any amount payable by a director shall be commenced more than six years after the occurrence of the act or omission for which the penalty is imposed.
If execution referred to in paragraph (2)(a) has issued, the amount recoverable from a director is the amount remaining unsatisfied after execution.
If a director pays an amount in respect of a corporation’s liability that is proved in liquidation, dissolution or bankruptcy proceedings,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the director is entitled to any preference that Her Majesty in right of Canada would have been entitled to if that amount had not been paid; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a certificate that relates to that amount has been registered, the director is entitled to an assignment of the certificate to the extent of the director’s payment and the Commission shall make the assignment.

Subsection.Text: A director who has satisfied a claim under this section is entitled to contribution from the other directors who are liable for the claim.

All amounts payable under section 38, 39, 43, 45, 46 or 46.1 are debts due to Her Majesty and are recoverable in the Federal Court or any other court of competent jurisdiction or in any other manner provided by this Act.
If benefits become payable to a claimant, the amount of the indebtedness may be deducted and retained out of the benefits.
No amount due under this section may be recovered more than 72 months after the day on which the liability arose.
A limitation period established by subsection (3) does not run when there is pending an appeal or other review of a decision establishing the liability.

No benefit period shall be established for a person unless the person makes an initial claim for benefits in accordance with section 50 and the regulations and proves that the person is qualified to receive benefits.

No benefit period shall be established unless the claimant supplies information in the form and manner directed by the Commission, giving the claimant’s employment circumstances and the circumstances pertaining to any interruption of earnings, and such other information as the Commission may require.
On receiving an initial claim for benefits, the Commission shall decide whether the claimant is qualified to receive benefits and notify the claimant of its decision.
A person is not entitled to receive benefits for a week of unemployment until the person makes a claim for benefits for that week in accordance with section 50 and the regulations and proves that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person meets the requirements for receiving benefits; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no circumstances or conditions exist that have the effect of disentitling or disqualifying the person from receiving benefits.

Subsection.Text: The Commission shall give the benefit of the doubt to the claimant on the issue of whether any circumstances or conditions exist that have the effect of disqualifying the claimant under section 30 or disentitling the claimant under section 31, 32 or 33, if the evidence on each side of the issue is equally balanced.
On receiving a claim for benefits, the Commission shall decide whether benefits are payable to the claimant for that week and notify the claimant of its decision.

A claimant who fails to fulfil or comply with a condition or requirement under this section is not entitled to receive benefits for as long as the condition or requirement is not fulfilled or complied with.

Subsection.MarginalNote: How a claim must be made
Subsection.Text: A claim for benefits shall be made in the manner directed at the office of the Commission that serves the area in which the claimant resides, or at such other place as is prescribed or directed by the Commission.
A claim for benefits shall be made by completing a form supplied or approved by the Commission, in the manner set out in instructions of the Commission.
A claim for benefits for a week of unemployment in a benefit period shall be made within the prescribed time.
The Commission may at any time require a claimant to provide additional information about their claim for benefits.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Making claim or providing information in person
Subsection.Text: The Commission may require a claimant or group or class of claimants to be at a suitable place at a suitable time in order to make a claim for benefits in person or provide additional information about a claim.

For the purpose of proving that a claimant is available for work, the Commission may require the claimant to register for employment at an agency administered by the Government of Canada or a provincial government and to report to the agency at such reasonable times as the Commission or agency directs.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Proof of efforts to obtain employment
Subsection.Text: For the purpose of proving that a claimant is available for work and unable to obtain suitable employment, the Commission may require the claimant to prove that the claimant is making reasonable and customary efforts to obtain suitable employment.

For the purpose of proving that the conditions of subsection 23.1(2) or 152.06(1) are met, the Commission may require the claimant to provide it with an additional certificate issued by a medical doctor.
A claimant shall provide the mailing address of their normal place of residence, unless otherwise permitted by the Commission.

The Commission may waive or vary any of the conditions and requirements of this section or the regulations whenever in its opinion the circumstances warrant the waiver or variation for the benefit of a claimant or a class or group of claimants.

Section.Text: If, in considering a claim for benefits, the Commission finds an indication from the documents relating to the claim that the loss of employment resulted from the claimant’s misconduct or that the claimant voluntarily left employment, the Commission shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: give the claimant and the employer an opportunity to provide information as to the reasons for the loss of employment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the information is provided, take it into account in determining the claim.

Subsection.Text: Despite section 111, but subject to subsection (5), the Commission may reconsider a claim for benefits within 36 months after the benefits have been paid or would have been payable.

If the Commission decides that a person has received money by way of benefits for which the person was not qualified or to which the person was not entitled, or has not received money for which the person was qualified and to which the person was entitled, the Commission must calculate the amount of the money and notify the claimant of its decision.
If the Commission decides that a person has received money by way of benefits for which the person was not qualified or to which the person was not entitled,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the amount calculated is repayable under section 43; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day that the Commission notifies the person of the amount is, for the purposes of subsection 47(3), the day on which the liability arises.

Subsection.Text: If the Commission decides that a person was qualified and entitled to receive money by way of benefits, and the money was not paid, the amount calculated is payable to the claimant.
If, in the opinion of the Commission, a false or misleading statement or representation has been made in connection with a claim, the Commission has 72 months within which to reconsider the claim.

Section.Text: If the Commission is required to notify a person of a decision under this Part, it may have that person notified in such manner as it considers adequate.
The Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the conditions on which the requirement under this Part or Part VII.1 of serving a waiting period may be waived;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: defining or determining what is a working day or working week in any employment or for the purposes of Part VII.1;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the conditions and circumstances under which a claimant

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: while self-employed or employed in employment that is not insurable employment, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: whose pattern of full-time employment differs from the normal and customary employment pattern of employed persons generally,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: is to be considered to have worked or not worked a full working week;

Paragraph.Label: (c.1)
Paragraph.Text: for determining the average number of weeks of regular benefits for the purposes of paragraph 7.1(6)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (c.2)
Paragraph.Text: setting out circumstances for the purposes of paragraphs 10(5.1)(c), 10(5.2)(c), 23.1(6)(c), 23.2(5)(c), 152.06(5)(c), 152.061(5)(c), 152.11(6)(c) and 152.11(6.1)(c);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: defining or determining who are dependent children, prescribing low-income family eligibility criteria and determining the amount of family supplements for the purposes of section 16 or 152.17;

Paragraph.Label: (d.1)
Paragraph.Text: determining, for the purposes of subsection 19(3) or 152.18(3), the period for which benefits were claimed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the deduction under section 19 of earnings and allowances mentioned in subsection 19(4);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: determining the amount to be deducted under subsection 20(2) from weekly benefits paid if the claimant normally works other than a five day week;

Paragraph.Label: (f.1)
Paragraph.Text: [Not in force]

Paragraph.Label: (f.2)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing classes of persons for the purposes of paragraph 23.1(1)(d) and paragraph (d) of the definition family member in subsection 152.01(1);

Paragraph.Label: (f.21)
Paragraph.Text: defining or determining what is a parent, a critically ill child and a specialist medical doctor for the purposes of subsections 23.2(1) and 152.061(1);

Paragraph.Label: (f.3)
Paragraph.Text: defining or determining what is care or support for the purposes of paragraphs 23.1(2)(b), 23.2(1)(a), 152.06(1)(b) and 152.061(1)(a);

Paragraph.Label: (f.4)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing classes of medical practitioners for the purposes of subsections 23.1(3), 23.2(2), 152.06(2) and 152.061(2) and setting out the circumstances in which a certificate may be issued by them under subsection 23.1(2), 23.2(1), 152.06(1) or 152.061(1);

Paragraph.Label: (f.5)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing a shorter period for the purposes of subsections 23.1(5) and 152.06(4) and prescribing a minimum number of weeks in relation to that shorter period for the purposes of subsections 12(4.3) and 152.14(7);

Paragraph.Label: (f.6)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing requirements for the purposes of paragraphs 23.1(7)(c), 23.2(6)(c), 23.2(7)(c), 152.06(6)(c), 152.061(6)(c) and 152.061(7)(c);

Paragraph.Label: (f.7)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing rules for the purposes of subsections 23.1(9), 23.2(8) and 152.061(8);

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: setting out the circumstances that constitute the commencement or termination of a stoppage of work for the purposes of section 36;

Paragraph.Label: (g.1)
Paragraph.Text: for defining as a major contravention for the purposes of subsection 39(5) anything that constitutes an act mentioned in subsection 39(1) or (3) and for setting or calculating the amount or maximum amount of the penalty for the major contravention, up to a maximum of $25,000;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the making of claims by, and the payment of benefits to, any person or agency on behalf of deceased or incapacitated persons or persons with mental disabilities;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: imposing additional conditions and terms with respect to the payment and receipt of benefits and restricting the amount or period of benefits in relation to persons who by custom of their occupation, trade or industry or under their agreement with an employer are paid in whole or in part by the piece or on a basis other than time;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: prohibiting the payment of benefits, in whole or in part, and restricting the amount of benefits payable, in relation to persons or to groups or classes of persons who work or have worked for any part of a year in an industry or occupation in which, in the opinion of the Commission, there is a period that occurs annually, at regular or irregular intervals, during which no work is performed by a significant number of persons engaged in that industry or occupation, for any or all weeks in that period;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: for the ratification of amounts paid to persons while they are not entitled to them and for writing off those amounts and any penalties under section 38, 39 or 65.1 and amounts owing under section 43, 45, 46, 46.1 or 65 and any costs recovered against those persons;

Paragraph.Label: (k.1)
Paragraph.Text: establishing criteria for defining or determining what constitutes suitable employment for different categories of claimants for the purposes of any provision of this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (k.2)
Paragraph.Text: establishing criteria for defining or determining what constitutes reasonable and customary efforts for the purposes of subsection 50(8);

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the proof of fulfilment of the conditions and the absence of the disqualification from receiving or continuing to receive benefits, and for that purpose requiring the attendance of insured persons at such offices or places and at such times as may be required;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the manner in which claims for benefits shall be made and the information to be provided with those claims;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the procedure to be followed for the consideration and the examination of claims and questions to be considered by officers of the Commission and the way in which a question may be raised as to the continuation of benefits in the case of a person in receipt of benefits;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the payment of benefits during any period intervening between an application for the determination of a question or a claim for benefits and the final determination of the question or claim;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the time and manner of paying benefits;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: requiring employers to provide information about any matter on which the fulfilment of conditions for the qualification and entitlement for receiving or continuing to receive benefits depends, prescribing the time and manner in which the information shall be provided and requiring the certification or affirmation of the information;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: providing the manner of ascertaining a claimant’s employment history if their employer has failed to provide a record of their employment on separation or the employer is not available or is unable to provide the necessary employment history because their records are destroyed or lost;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: defining and determining earnings for benefit purposes, determining the amount of those earnings and providing for the allocation of those earnings to weeks or other periods;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: establishing criteria for defining and determining what constitutes a supplemental unemployment benefit plan and providing for the making of those determinations, including the consideration of late applications, reconsidering determinations and appeals from determinations;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: defining and determining the circumstances in which and the time at which an interruption of earnings occurs;

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing conditions under which benefits may be paid in advance;

Paragraph.Label: (w)
Paragraph.Text: establishing regions appropriate for the purpose of applying this Part and Part VIII and delineating their boundaries based on geographical units established or used by Statistics Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (x)
Paragraph.Text: determining the regional rates of unemployment produced by Statistics Canada or the averages of those rates that shall apply to a claimant for the purposes of this Part and Part VIII and incorporating in those rates an estimate of the rates for status Indians living on Indian reserves;

Paragraph.Label: (y)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the information and evidence to be provided by a claimant to prove

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: inability to work because of illness, injury or quarantine, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: pregnancy or the expected date of confinement;

Paragraph.Label: (z)
Paragraph.Text: for carrying out the purposes and provisions of section 14, including regulations

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: respecting the circumstances under which, the criteria by which and the manner in which

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: weeks are to be considered as weeks for which a claimant has insurable earnings during a calculation period, including the number of those weeks to be considered in that period, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: amounts are to be considered as the insurable earnings for any week or number of weeks in that period, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for allocating insurable earnings to a calculation period, for example by including them in that period or excluding them from that period;

Paragraph.Label: (z.1)
Paragraph.Text: for allocating hours of insurable employment to a qualifying period, for example by including them in that period or excluding them from that period;

Paragraph.Label: (z.2)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the circumstances in which a claimant who leaves employment in accordance with an employer work-force reduction process that preserves the employment of coworkers may, notwithstanding section 30, be paid benefits, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: what constitutes an employer work-force reduction process for the purposes of the regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (z.3)
Paragraph.Text: reducing the special benefits payable when allowances, money or other benefits are payable to a claimant under a plan other than one established under a provincial law; and

Paragraph.Label: (z.4)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing anything that by section 2 or this Part is to be prescribed.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations for establishing how many hours of insurable employment a person has, including regulations providing that persons whose earnings are not paid on an hourly basis are deemed to have hours of insurable employment as established in accordance with the regulations.

If the Commission considers that it is not possible to apply the provisions of the regulations, it may authorize an alternative method of establishing how many hours of insurable employment a person has.
The Commission may at any time alter the authorized method or rescind the authorization, subject to any conditions that it considers appropriate.

The Commission may enter into agreements with employers or employees to provide for alternative methods of establishing how many hours of insurable employment persons have and the Commission may at any time rescind the agreements.

Heading.Label: PART II
Heading.TitleText: Employment Benefits and National Employment Service

Section.Text: The purpose of this Part is to help maintain a sustainable employment insurance system through the establishment of employment benefits for insured participants and the maintenance of a national employment service.

Subsection.Text: Employment benefits and support measures under this Part shall be established in accordance with the following guidelines:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: harmonization with provincial employment initiatives to ensure that there is no unnecessary overlap or duplication;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: reduction of dependency on unemployment benefits by helping individuals obtain or keep employment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: co-operation and partnership with other governments, employers, community-based organizations and other interested organizations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: flexibility to allow significant decisions about implementation to be made at a local level;

Paragraph.Label: (d.1)
Paragraph.Text: availability of assistance under the benefits and measures in either official language where there is significant demand for that assistance in that language;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: commitment by persons receiving assistance under the benefits and measures to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: achieving the goals of the assistance,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: taking primary responsibility for identifying their employment needs and locating services necessary to allow them to meet those needs, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: if appropriate, sharing the cost of the assistance; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: implementation of the benefits and measures within a framework for evaluating their success in assisting persons to obtain or keep employment.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Working in concert with provincial governments
Subsection.Text: To give effect to the purpose and guidelines of this Part, the Commission shall work in concert with the government of each province in which employment benefits and support measures are to be implemented in designing the benefits and measures, determining how they are to be implemented and establishing the framework for evaluating their success.
The Commission shall invite the government of each province to enter into agreements for the purposes of subsection (2) or any other agreements authorized by this Part.

Section.Text: In this Part, insured participant means an insured person who requests assistance under employment benefits and, when requesting the assistance, is an unemployed person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for whom a benefit period is established or whose benefit period has ended within the previous 60 months; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: who would have had a benefit period established for them within the previous 60 months if it were not for the fact that they have had fewer than the hours referred to in subsection 7(4) in the last 52 weeks before what would have been their qualifying period and who, during what would have been that qualifying period, has had at least the number of hours of insurable employment indicated in the table set out in subsection 7(2) or 7.1(1) in relation to their applicable regional rate of unemployment.

Section.Text: The Commission may establish employment benefits to enable insured participants to obtain employment, including benefits to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: encourage employers to hire them;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: encourage them to accept employment by offering incentives such as temporary earnings supplements;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: help them start businesses or become self-employed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide them with employment opportunities through which they can gain work experience to improve their long-term employment prospects; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: help them obtain skills for employment, ranging from basic to advanced skills.

Subsection.Text: The Commission shall maintain a national employment service to provide information on employment opportunities across Canada to help workers find suitable employment and help employers find suitable workers.
The Commission shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: collect information concerning employment for workers and workers seeking employment and, to the extent the Commission considers necessary, make the information available with a view to assisting workers to obtain employment for which they are suited and assisting employers to obtain workers most suitable to their needs; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that in referring a worker seeking employment there will be no discrimination on a prohibited ground of discrimination within the meaning of the Canadian Human Rights Act or because of political affiliation, but nothing in this paragraph prohibits the national employment service from giving effect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any limitation, specification or preference based on a bona fide occupational requirement, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any special program, plan or arrangement mentioned in section 16 of the Canadian Human Rights Act.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations for the purposes of subsections (1) and (2).
In support of the national employment service, the Commission may establish support measures to support

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: organizations that provide employment assistance services to unemployed persons;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: employers, employee or employer associations, community groups and communities in developing and implementing strategies for dealing with labour force adjustments and meeting human resource requirements; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: research and innovative projects to identify better ways of helping persons prepare for, return to or keep employment and be productive participants in the labour force.

Subsection.Text: Support measures established under paragraph (4)(b) shall not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide assistance for employed persons unless they are facing a loss of their employment; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide direct federal government assistance for the provision of labour market training without the agreement of the government of the province in which the assistance is provided.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of implementing employment benefits and support measures, the Commission may, in accordance with terms and conditions approved by the Treasury Board, provide financial assistance in the form of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: grants or contributions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: loans, loan guarantees or suretyships;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: payments for any service provided at the request of the Commission; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: vouchers to be exchanged for services and payments for the provision of the services.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may not provide any financial assistance in a province in support of employment benefits mentioned in paragraph 59(e) without the agreement of the government of the province.
Payments under paragraph (1)(c) include the following transitional payments, which may not be made under this section more than three years after it comes into force:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: payments to a public or private educational institution for providing a course or program of instruction or training at the request of the Commission under employment benefits authorized by paragraph 59(e); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: payments to a province in respect of the course or program if it is provided by a public educational institution and there is an agreement between the government of the province and the Commission to remunerate the province for all or part of the cost of providing the course or program.

Section.MarginalNote: Agreements for administering employment benefits and support measures
Section.Text: The Commission may, with the approval of the Minister, enter into an agreement or arrangement for the administration of employment benefits or support measures on its behalf by a department, board or agency of the Government of Canada, another government or government agency in Canada or any other public or private organization.

Section.MarginalNote: Agreements for paying costs of similar benefits and measures

Subsection.Text: The Commission may, with the approval of the Minister, enter into an agreement with a government or government agency in Canada or any other public or private organization to provide for the payment of contributions for all or a portion of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any costs of benefits or measures provided by the government, government agency or organization that are similar to employment benefits or support measures under this Part and are consistent with the purpose and guidelines of this Part; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any administration costs that the government, government agency or organization incurs in providing the benefits or measures.

Subsection.Text: An agreement may be entered into under subsection (1) with a government even if the benefits provided by that government are provided only for an insured participant as defined in section 58 as it read immediately before the day on which this subsection comes into force.

Section.Text: Contributions that are to be paid under an agreement that, before the day on which this section comes into force, was entered into with a government under section 63 to provide for the payment of contributions for all or a portion of the costs of benefits provided by the government that are similar to employment benefits under this Part shall be paid only for costs of benefits for an insured participant as defined in section 58 as it read immediately before that day.
A decision of the Commission made in relation to employment benefits or support measures, other than a decision under section 65.1, is not subject to review under section 112.
A person is liable to repay the following amounts paid under section 61:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: principal and interest on a loan to the person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an amount paid on a guarantee or suretyship of a loan made to the person; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an amount paid to the person to which the person is not entitled.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may impose on a person to whom financial assistance has been provided under section 61 a penalty for each of the following acts or omissions if the Commission becomes aware of facts that in its opinion establish that the person has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to an application or request for the assistance,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: made a representation that the person knew was false or misleading, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: made a declaration that the person knew was false or misleading because of the non-disclosure of facts; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: without good cause failed to attend, carry out or complete the course, program or activity for which the assistance was provided or was expelled from it.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may set the amount of the penalty for each act or omission at not more than the amount of the financial assistance that was provided.
The penalty shall not be imposed if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a prosecution for the act or omission has been initiated against the person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 36 months have passed since the day on which the act or omission occurred.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may rescind the imposition of the penalty, or reduce the penalty, on the presentation of new facts or on being satisfied that the penalty was imposed without knowledge of, or on the basis of a mistake as to, some material fact.

Amounts repayable under section 65 and penalties under section 65.1 are debts due to Her Majesty and are recoverable in the Federal Court or any other court of competent jurisdiction or in any other manner provided by this Act.
If an amount becomes payable to the person under section 61, the amount of their indebtedness to Her Majesty may be recovered out of the amount payable.
No amount due under this section may be recovered more than 72 months after the day on which the liability arose.

Section.Text: In this Part, actuary means the Fellow of the Canadian Institute of Actuaries whose services are engaged by the Commission under subsection 28(4) of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (7) and section 66.32, the Commission shall set the premium rate for each year in order to generate just enough premium revenue to ensure that, at the end of the seven-year period that commences at the beginning of that year, the total of the amounts credited to the Employment Insurance Operating Account after December 31, 2008 is equal to the total of the amounts charged to that Account after that date.
Despite subsection (1), the premium rate for the years 2015 and 2016 is 1.88%.
Sections 66.1 to 66.31 apply in the years 2014 and 2015 even though the premium rates for the years 2015 and 2016 are set under subsection (1.1).
The Commission shall set the premium rate based on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information provided under sections 66.1 and 66.2;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the actuary’s report provided under section 66.3 for that year;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any regulations made under section 69;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any changes, announced by the Minister on or before July 22 in a year, to payments to be made under paragraph 77(1)(a), (b) or (c) during the following year; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any other information that the Commission considers relevant.

Subsection.Text: [No subsection (3)]
The premium rate may not be increased or decreased by more than five one-hundredths of one per cent (0.05%) from one year to the next.
Despite subsection (7), the premium rate may be decreased by more than five one-hundredths of one per cent (0.05%) from 2016 to 2017.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Governor in Council — maximum change in premium rate
Subsection.Text: On the joint recommendation of the Minister and the Minister of Finance, the Governor in Council may change the maximum percentage referred to in subsection (7) by which the premium rate may be increased or decreased from one year to the next, if the Governor in Council considers it to be in the public interest.
On or before September 14 in a year, the Commission shall set the premium rate for the following year.
The Minister shall, on or before July 22 in a year, provide the actuary and the Commission with the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the Minister has made an announcement referred to in paragraph 66(2)(e), the forecast change in the amount of the payments to be made during each of the following seven years under paragraph 77(1)(a), (b) or (c), as the case may be;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the forecast costs to be paid under paragraphs 77(1)(d), (d.1) and (g) during each of the following seven years, including any forecast change in those costs resulting from any change to the payments referred to in paragraph (a);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the total of the amounts charged to the Employment Insurance Operating Account as of the last day of the most recent month for which that total is known by the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any prescribed information.

Subsection.Text: On the recommendation of the Minister, the Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing information referred to in paragraph (1)(d).
The Minister of Finance shall, on or before July 22 in a year, provide the actuary and the Commission with the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the most current available forecast values of the economic variables that are relevant to the determination under section 66 of a premium rate for the following year;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amounts forecast under subparagraphs 77.1(a)(i) and (ii) and the total estimated under subparagraph 77.1(a)(iii); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any prescribed information.

Subsection.Text: On the recommendation of the Minister of Finance, the Governor in Council may make regulations prescribing information referred to in paragraph (1)(c).

Section.Text: The actuary shall prepare actuarial forecasts and estimates for the purposes of sections 4, 66 and 69 and shall, on or before August 22 in a year, provide the Commission with a report that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the forecast premium rate for the following year and a detailed analysis in support of the forecast;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the calculations performed for the purposes of sections 4 and 69;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the information provided under section 66.1; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the source of the data, the actuarial and economic assumptions and the actuarial methodology used.

Subsection.Text: The Commission shall, on or before August 31 in a year, provide the Minister and the Minister of Finance with the report referred to in section 66.3 and a summary of that report.
The Commission shall, on the day on which a premium rate is set under section 66 or 66.32, make available to the public the report and its summary.
After a premium rate is set, the Minister shall cause the report and its summary to be laid before each House of Parliament on any of the next 10 days during which that House is sitting.

Section.MarginalNote: Premium rate setting by Governor in Council

Subsection.Text: On the joint recommendation of the Minister and the Minister of Finance, the Governor in Council may, on or before September 30 in a year,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the Governor in Council considers it to be in the public interest, substitute a premium rate for the following year that is different from the one set by the Commission under section 66; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the Commission has not set a premium rate under that section by September 14 in the year, set one for the following year.

Subsection.Text: Subsection 66(7) does not apply to the setting of the premium rate under subsection (1).

Section.Text: If the calculation of a premium rate under section 66 or 66.32 results in a rate that includes a fraction of one per cent, the resulting percentage is to be rounded to the nearest one hundredth of one per cent or, if the resulting percentage is equidistant from two one-hundredths of one percent, to the higher of them.
As soon as possible after a premium rate is set under section 66 or 66.32, the Commission shall publish it in Part I of the Canada Gazette.
For greater certainty, the User Fees Act does not apply in respect of the premium rate set under section 66 or 66.32 or the premiums determined under sections 67 and 68.

Subject to section 70, a person employed in insurable employment shall pay, by deduction as provided in subsection 82(1), a premium equal to their insurable earnings multiplied by the premium rate set under section 66 or 66.32, as the case may be.
Subject to sections 69 and 70, an employer shall pay a premium equal to 1.4 times the employees’ premiums that the employer is required to deduct under subsection 82(1).

Subsection.Text: The Commission shall, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations to provide a system for reducing the employer’s premium when

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the payment of any allowances, money or other benefits because of illness, injury, quarantine, pregnancy, child care, compassionate care or a child’s critical illness under a plan that covers insured persons employed by the employer, other than one established under provincial law, would have the effect of reducing the special benefits payable to the insured persons; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the insured persons will benefit from the reduction of the employer’s premium in an amount at least equal to 5/12 of the reduction.

Subsection.Text: The Commission shall, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations to provide a system for reducing the employer’s and employee’s premiums, the premiums under Part VII.1 or all those premiums, when the payment of any allowances, money or other benefits because of illness, injury, quarantine, pregnancy, child care, compassionate care or a child’s critical illness under a provincial law to insured persons, or to self-employed persons, as the case may be, would have the effect of reducing or eliminating the special benefits payable to those insured persons or the benefits payable to those self-employed persons.
The regulations may include provisions

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the manner and time for making an application for a premium reduction;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the standards that must be met by a plan to qualify for a premium reduction and the time during which the plan must be in effect;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the method for determining the amount of reduction for plans that meet the prescribed standards and the use to be made of actuarial calculations and estimates;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the manner in which insured persons are to benefit from the premium reduction;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the making of decisions relating to premium reduction and appeals in cases of dispute;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing how the insured earnings of insured persons will be reported by employers to the Canada Revenue Agency; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: generally, providing for any other matters necessary for carrying out the purposes and provisions of subsections (1) and (2).

Subsection.Text: If an application for an employer’s premium reduction is made within 36 months after the time prescribed for making it, the Commission may, subject to prescribed conditions, regard the application as having been made at the prescribed time if the applicant shows that there was good cause for the delay throughout the period beginning at the prescribed time and ending on the day when the application was made.

The Commission may reconsider any decision relating to an employer’s premium reduction within 36 months after the date of the decision and any new decision that it makes shall apply in place of the reconsidered decision.

The reference to the payment of allowances, money or other benefits because of compassionate care in subsections (1) and (2) means the payment of allowances, money or other benefits for the same or substantially the same reasons for which benefits are payable under section 23.1.

The reference to the payment of allowances, money or other benefits because of a child’s critical illness in subsections (1) and (2) means the payment of allowances, money or other benefits for the same or substantially the same reasons for which benefits are payable under section 23.2.

Section.Text: If insurable earnings are paid to a person after the end of the year in which their insurable employment occurred, the insurable employment is, for the purposes of determining insurable earnings and premiums payable, deemed to have occurred in the year in which the insurable earnings are paid.
There is established in the accounts of Canada an account to be known as the Employment Insurance Operating Account.
There shall be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all amounts received under Parts I and III to IX, as or on account of premiums, fines, penalties, interest, repayment of overpaid benefits and benefit repayment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all amounts collected by the Commission for services rendered to other government departments or agencies or to the public; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all amounts received on account of principal or interest on loans made by the Commission under Part II or as repayment of overpayments made by the Commission under that Part.

Section.MarginalNote: Credits to Employment Insurance Operating Account
Section.Text: There shall be credited to the Employment Insurance Operating Account and charged to the Consolidated Revenue Fund

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an amount in each year equal to the amount receivable as or on account of premiums payable for that year under this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other amounts provided out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund appropriated by Parliament for any purpose related to employment insurance and administered by the Commission; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an amount equal to all benefit repayments receivable under Part VII.

Section.Text: There shall be credited to the Employment Insurance Operating Account on August 1, 2010 the amount determined by the Minister of Finance that corresponds to the cost of the benefit enhancement measures under this Act, provided for in the budget tabled in Parliament on January 27, 2009 in which the cost is estimated to be $2,900,000,000.

There shall be credited to the Employment Insurance Operating Account and charged to the Consolidated Revenue Fund an amount equal to the premiums required to be paid by Her Majesty in right of Canada as employer’s premiums for persons employed in insurable employment by Her Majesty in right of Canada.

Section.MarginalNote: Other credits to Employment Insurance Operating Account
Section.Text: There shall be credited to the Employment Insurance Operating Account all amounts paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund that are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: received as or on account of penalties imposed under section 38, 39 or 65.1 and repayments of overpaid benefits, except interest and penalties on benefit repayment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: collected by the Commission for services rendered to other government departments or agencies or to the public;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: received on account of principal or interest on loans made by the Commission under Part II;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: received as repayments of overpayments by the Commission under section 61 for employment benefits and support measures authorized by Part II;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: received as repayments of overpayments by the Commission under agreements entered into under section 63; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: received as interest under section 80.1.

Subsection.Text: There shall be paid out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund and charged to the Employment Insurance Operating Account

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all amounts paid as or on account of benefits under this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all amounts paid under section 61 for employment benefits and support measures authorized by Part II;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all amounts paid under paragraph 63(1)(a);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the costs of administering this Act, including administration fees or costs paid under section 62 or paragraph 63(1)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (d.1)
Paragraph.Text: the costs of administering sections 28.1 and 28.2 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the costs of administering Part 5 of the Department of Employment and Social Development Act in respect of appeals respecting this Act.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding the Financial Administration Act, amounts mentioned in paragraph (1)(a) shall be paid by special warrants drawn on the Receiver General and issued by the Commission by electronic means or bearing the printed signature of the Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson of the Commission, and amounts mentioned in paragraphs (1)(b) and (c) may be paid by the special warrants.
The special warrants are negotiable without charge at any financial institution in Canada.
On or before July 22 in a year,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister of Finance shall

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: forecast the amount to be credited to the Employment Insurance Operating Account under sections 73 to 75 during the year,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: forecast the amount to be charged, during the year, to that Account under subsection 77(1) based on, among other things, information provided by the Minister, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: estimate the total, at December 31 of the immediately preceding year, of the amounts credited to that Account; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister shall estimate the total, at December 31 of the immediately preceding year, of the amounts charged to that Account.

Section.MarginalNote: Maximum amount that may be paid under Part II
Section.Text: The total amount that may be paid out by the Commission under section 61 and paragraph 63(1)(a) and charged to the Employment Insurance Operating Account under this Part in a fiscal year must not exceed 0.8% of the insurable earnings of all insured persons from which the prescribed amount is deducted under subsection 82(1) in that year as or on account of employee’s premiums, as estimated by the Commission and set out in the Main Estimates tabled in Parliament.
The Minister shall, with the concurrence of the Minister of Finance,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Treasury Board for approval a plan for each fiscal year estimating the amounts to be paid for that year under Part II; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have the plan included in the Main Estimates tabled in Parliament for the fiscal year.

Subsection.Text: The Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations respecting the payment of interest on amounts owing to Her Majesty under this Act, other than Parts IV and VII, including regulations prescribing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: rates of interest, or the manner of calculating rates of interest, payable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: terms and conditions for the imposition and payment of interest; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: terms and conditions under which the Commission may waive, reduce or write off the interest payable.

Subsection.Text: Interest payable under this section is a debt due to Her Majesty and may be recovered in the Federal Court or any other court of competent jurisdiction or in any other manner provided by this Act, including the manner in which an amount owing under Part I may be recovered under subsection 47(2) or section 126.
No interest due under this section may be recovered more than 72 months after the day on which the liability to pay it arose.
Section 155.1 of the Financial Administration Act does not apply in relation to amounts owing to Her Majesty under this Act, other than Parts IV and VII.

Heading.Label: PART IV
Heading.TitleText: Insurable Earnings and Collection of Premiums

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: authorized person means a person authorized by the Minister for the purposes of this Part;
judge means a judge of a superior court having jurisdiction in the province where the matter arises or a judge of the Federal Court;
Minister means the Minister of National Revenue.

Subsection.Text: Every employer paying remuneration to a person they employ in insurable employment shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deduct the prescribed amount from the remuneration as or on account of the employee’s premium payable by that insured person under section 67 for any period for which the remuneration is paid; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: remit the amount, together with the employer’s premium payable by the employer under section 68 for that period, to the Receiver General at the prescribed time and in the prescribed manner.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Maximum deduction by a particular employer
Subsection.Text: The employer shall not make any deduction as or on account of the person’s premium for a year if in that year the insurable earnings paid by the employer to the person have reached the maximum yearly insurable earnings.

If the employer is a prescribed person at the prescribed time, the remittance shall be made to the account of the Receiver General at a financial institution, within the meaning that would be assigned by the definition financial institution in subsection 190(1) of the Income Tax Act if it were read without reference to paragraphs (d) and (e) of that subsection.

For the purpose of subsection (3), a prescribed person referred to in that subsection is deemed to have remitted an amount to the account of the Receiver General at a financial institution referred to in that subsection if the prescribed person has remitted the amount to the Receiver General at least one day before the day on which the amount is due.

Subject to subsection (5), an employer who fails to deduct and remit an amount from the remuneration of an insured person as and when required under subsection (1) is liable to pay to Her Majesty the whole amount that should have been deducted and remitted from the time it should have been deducted.
An employer is not liable for failing to make a deduction from the remuneration of an insured person or for any amount that should have been deducted if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the employer is informed in writing in a ruling under section 90 that the employer is not required to make the deduction,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the ruling is not based on information provided by the employer to the Minister that was incorrect in a material particular, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it is subsequently decided under section 91 or 103 that the deduction should have been made,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: but once the decision under section 91 or 103 is communicated to the employer, the employer is liable without interest or penalties under this Act to pay the premium required to be paid by the employer with respect to the insured person.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Deduction from subsequent payment of remuneration
Subsection.Text: An employer who fails to deduct the employee’s premium as required by subsection (1) from a payment of remuneration to an insured person may deduct an amount equal to it from any subsequent payment of remuneration made to the insured person within 12 months after making the payment from which the deduction was required, but the employer may not deduct, in addition to the premium required by subsection (1), more than one other such premium that the employer previously failed to deduct.
If an amount has been deducted under subsection (1), it is deemed for all purposes to have been received at that time by the insured person to whom the remuneration was payable.

If an employer has failed to remit to the Receiver General an amount that the employer was required to remit at the time when it was required, the employer shall pay to the Receiver General interest on that amount at the prescribed rate computed from the day on which the employer was so required to remit the amount to the day of remittance of the amount to the Receiver General.
Every employer who in a year fails to remit to the Receiver General an amount that the employer is required to remit at the time when it is required is liable to a penalty of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subject to paragraph (b), if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the Receiver General receives that amount on or before the day it was due, but that amount is not paid in the manner required, 3% of that amount,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Receiver General receives that amount

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: no more than three days after it was due, 3% of that amount,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: more than three days and no more than five days after it was due, 5% of that amount, or

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: more than five days and no more than seven days after it was due, 7% of that amount, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: that amount is not paid or remitted on or before the seventh day after it was due, 10% of that amount; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 20% of the amount if at the time of the failure a penalty under this subsection was payable by the employer for an amount that the employer was required to remit during the year and the failure was made knowingly or under circumstances amounting to gross negligence.

Section.Text: If, in a year after 2003, one employer immediately succeeds another as the employer of an employee as a result of the formation or dissolution of a corporation or the acquisition — with the agreement of the former employer or by operation of law — of all or part of an undertaking or business of the former employer, the successor employer may, for the application of section 82, take into account the amounts deducted, remitted or paid under this Act by the former employer in respect of the year in relation to the employment of the employee as if they had been deducted, remitted or paid by the successor employer.
