Paragraph.Text: the premium required in respect of their self-employed earnings for the preceding year.

Subsection.Text: The Minister of National Revenue may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations, prescribing a rate for the purposes of each of subsections (1) and (2).

Every self-employed person who fails to file a return of their self-employed earnings for a year as and when required by section 152.22 is liable to a penalty of five per cent of the part of the amount of the premium required to be paid by them for the year that remained unpaid at the expiry of the time the return was required to be filed, except that, if that person is liable to a penalty under subsection 162(1) or (2) of the Income Tax Act in respect of the year, the Minister of National Revenue may reduce the penalty to which the person is liable under this section or may remit the penalty in whole or in part.
Every person who fails to file a return as required by subsection 152.22(3) is liable to a penalty of $5 for each day of default, to a maximum of $50.

Subject to this Part and except as otherwise provided by regulation made under subsection (2), the provisions of Divisions I and J of Part I of the Income Tax Act with respect to payment of tax, assessments, objections to assessments, appeals, interest, penalties and excess refunds, and the provisions of Part XV of that Act (except section 221) and subsections 248(7) and (11) of that Act apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, in relation to any amount paid or payable as or on account of the premium for a year in respect of self-employed earnings as though that amount were an amount paid or payable as or on account of tax under that Act.
The Minister of National Revenue may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: exempting any provision of Divisions I and J of Part I of the Income Tax Act from the application of subsection (1); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: specifying that any provisions of either of those Divisions apply with the modifications specified in the regulations.

Section.MarginalNote: Priority in which payment to be applied
Section.Text: If any payment is made by a person to the Minister of National Revenue on account of taxes specified in section 228 of the Income Tax Act and of a premium under this Part in respect of self-employed earnings, despite any direction made by the person making the payment with respect to its application, the part of the payment that would be applied under that section in payment of tax under the Income Tax Act is, subject to section 37 of the Canada Pension Plan, to be applied in payment of a premium under this Part and is deemed to be a payment on account of the premium, and to the extent of the amount so applied, does not discharge liability for tax under the Income Tax Act, and any amount then remaining is to be applied in payment of tax under the Income Tax Act and discharges the liability of the person making the payment for that tax to the extent of that amount.

Section.MarginalNote: Refund of excess premium in respect of self-employed earnings

Subsection.Text: If a self-employed person has paid, on account of the premium they are required to pay for a year in respect of their self-employed earnings, an amount in excess of the premium, the Minister of National Revenue

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: may refund that part of the amount so paid in excess of the premium on sending the notice of assessment of the premium, without any application having been made for the refund; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall make the refund after sending the notice of assessment, if an application for the refund is made in writing by the self-employed person not later than three years after the end of the year.

Subsection.Text: Subsections 96(11) to (13) apply in respect of refunds under subsection (1).

Subject to subsections (2) and (3), all the provisions of this Act, except sections 5 to 37, 48 and 56 to 65.2, that are not inconsistent with the provisions of this Part apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to this Part.
For the purposes of this Part,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 86(1) applies as though the reference to “an employer” in that subsection were a reference to “a self-employed person”; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 88(5) applies as though the reference to “this Part” were a reference to “Part VII.1”.

Subsection.Text: Section 102 applies, with any modifications that the circumstances require, in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: offences under paragraphs 106(4)(a), (d) and (e) committed in relation to any provision of this Part or regulations made under sections 152.26 and 152.28;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: offences under section 152.32; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any matter referred to in any of sections 152.21 to 152.3 or that relates to the application of any of those sections.

Subsection.Text: Section 125 applies in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: offences under subsections 135(1) and 136(2) committed by self-employed persons and offences committed by them in relation to the contravention of any provision of regulations made under this Part, except regulations made under sections 152.26 and 152.28; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any matter referred to in this Part or that relates to the application of this Part, other than a matter referred to in any of sections 152.21 to 152.3 or in regulations made under sections 152.26 and 152.28.

Section.Text: The Minister of National Revenue may authorize an officer or a class of officers to exercise powers or perform duties of that Minister under this Part.

Every person who contravenes section 152.22 is guilty of an offence and, in addition to any penalty otherwise provided, is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not less than $25 a day for each day the offence continues, to a maximum of $1,000.
The Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: defining or determining what is a week of unemployment for a self-employed person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: setting out the circumstances under which agreements referred to in subsection 152.02(4) are deemed to be terminated;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fixing, for any year, an amount for the purposes of subparagraph 152.07(1)(d)(i), or establishing a manner for determining that amount, which amount may not be less than $6,000;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for determining the average number of weeks of benefits for the purposes of paragraph 152.07(3)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: specifying, for the purpose of subsection 152.03(4), the circumstances when self-employed persons are deemed to be not working; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing anything that by this Part is to be prescribed.

Section.Text: Five years after the day on which this Part comes into force, the Minister must cause a review of this Part and its administration and operation to be conducted.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding anything in this Act, the Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make such regulations as it deems necessary respecting the establishment and operation of a scheme of employment insurance for self-employed persons engaged in fishing, including regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: including as a self-employed person engaged in fishing any person engaged in an activity or occupation related to or incidental to fishing; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: including as an employer of a self-employed person engaged in fishing any person with whom the self-employed person enters into a contractual or other commercial relationship in respect of their occupation as a self-employed person engaged in fishing.

Subsection.Text: The scheme established by the regulations may, with respect to any matter, be different from the provisions of this Act relating to that matter.
The Minister shall table the regulations in the House of Commons within three sitting days after the day on which they are made.

The regulations come into force on the 10th sitting day after the day on which they are tabled, or on any later day specified in the regulations, unless a motion to repeal them, signed by not fewer than 30 members of the House of Commons, is filed with the Speaker of the House of Commons before the 10th sitting day.

If a motion to repeal the regulations is filed with the Speaker of the House of Commons in accordance with subsection (4), it shall be taken up and considered by the House of Commons within five sitting days after the day on which it is filed.

The motion shall be taken up after the ordinary hour of daily adjournment, for a period of not more than four hours, and at the end of the debate the Speaker of the House of Commons shall, without delay or further debate or amendment, put every question necessary for the disposition of the motion.

If the motion is adopted, the regulations are repealed, and if the motion is defeated, the regulations come into force on the day after the day on which the motion is defeated or on any later day specified in the regulations.
The regulations are repealed if Parliament is prorogued or dissolved before the motion is disposed of or, if no motion has been filed, before the end of the period mentioned in subsection (4).
For the purpose of this section, sitting day means a day on which the House of Commons is sitting.

Despite anything in this Act, the Commission shall, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make any regulations it considers necessary respecting the establishment and operation of a scheme to ensure that special benefits are provided to insured persons who have at least 600 hours of insurable employment in their qualifying period but who do not qualify to receive benefits under section 7, including regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for establishing requirements to qualify to receive the benefits, the duration of entitlement to the benefits, benefit rates, disentitlement and disqualification from receiving the benefits and benefit repayment requirements; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: varying the application of any other provision of this Act in relation to persons who have made claims under this Part and who subsequently make claims under Part I or VIII.

Subsection.Text: The scheme established by the regulations may, with respect to any matter, be different from the provisions of this Act relating to that matter.

The scheme established by the regulations may not provide special benefits to persons who are subject to an increase under section 7.1 in the number of hours of insurable employment required to qualify for benefits.

Despite any other provisions of this Act, if the Government of Canada has entered into an agreement with a province in respect of a provincial law that has the effect of reducing or eliminating special benefits, or benefits under Part VII.1, payable as described in subsection 69(2), the Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, for the purposes of implementing the agreement and taking into account the application or effect of the provincial law, make any regulations that it considers necessary, including regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the manner in which and the extent to which any provision of this Act or the regulations applies; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: adapting any provision of this Act or the regulations.

Subsection.Text: The regulations may provide for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the making of any financial adjustments and for the crediting or charging of the amount of any of those adjustments to the Employment Insurance Operating Account, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: refunds of overpayments with respect to employees’ premiums and premiums under Part VII.1,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: adjustment payments between the prov­ince and the Government of Canada with respect to premiums, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: reimbursement by the province of benefits paid by the Government of Canada in accordance with any administrative agreement between the province and the Government of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the exchange of any information obtained under the provincial law or this Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the administration of benefits payable under this Act to persons employed or residing in the province or who have made a claim under the provincial law — or to self-employed persons, within the meaning of subsection 152.01(1), who work or reside in the province or who have made a claim under the provincial law — and the increase or decrease in the amount of benefits payable and in the number of weeks for which benefits may be paid under this Act to and in respect of those persons.

Heading.Label: PART IX
Heading.TitleText: Repeals, Transitional Provisions, Related and Conditional Amendments and Coming into Force

Section.Text: A training allowance being paid under section 5 of the National Training Act when it is repealed may continue to be paid in accordance with that Act and the regulations made under it, as they read immediately before the repeal of that Act, until the conclusion of the course to which the allowance relates.
An agreement under section 7 of the National Training Act in effect when it is repealed continues in effect according to the terms of the agreement.

Section.MarginalNote: Benefit periods beginning before this section comes into force

Subsection.Text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, all matters relating to a claim for benefits during a benefit period beginning before the Unemployment Insurance Act (the “former Act”) is repealed shall be dealt with under that Act, including any amendments that may be made by Bill C-31, introduced in the second session of the 35th Parliament and entitled An Act to implement certain provisions of the budget tabled in Parliament on March 6, 1996.

Subsection 70(2) of the former Act applies in respect of appeals under that Act except that the Tax Court of Canada need not give reasons in writing for its decision but may give reasons in writing where, in a particular case, the Court deems it advisable.

Subsection 19(3) of this Act applies to claimants who fail to declare all or some of their earnings in a period determined under the regulations beginning on or after January 5, 1997, but the Commission may make deductions under subparagraph 19(3)(a)(i) on or after that date in respect of any failure to declare earnings for such a period beginning after June 30, 1996.
Subsection 19(4) of this Act applies to claimants who begin attending a course or program after the former Act is repealed.
Section 23 of this Act applies in place of section 20 of the former Act to claimants claiming benefits for the care of children born or placed for adoption after that Act is repealed.
Section 25 of the former Act applies only to claimants employed on job creation projects under that section when that Act is repealed.
Section 26 of the former Act applies only to claimants in a course or program to which they are referred under that section before that Act is repealed.

Sections 27 to 33 of this Act apply in place of sections 27 to 28.3 of the former Act in respect of events occurring after that Act is repealed that give rise to a disentitlement or disqualification under those sections and, for the purpose of applying those sections, a reference in the former Act to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: section 27 shall be read as a reference to section 27 of this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: section 28 shall be read as a reference to section 29 of this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: section 28.1 shall be read as a reference to section 31 of this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: section 28.2 shall be read as a reference to section 32 of this Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: section 28.3 shall be read as a reference to section 33 of this Act.

Subsection.Text: Section 145 of this Act applies in place of section 123 of the former Act in respect of benefits paid after December 31, 1995.

Section.MarginalNote: Hours of insurable employment and earnings before 1997
Section.Text: For the purpose of calculating after 1996 how many hours of insurable employment and the amount of insurable earnings a claimant has under this Act, other than Part VIII, insurable employment and insurable earnings occurring

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before June 30, 1996 shall be determined in accordance with the former Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on or after June 30, 1996 but before January 5, 1997 shall be determined in accordance with this Act, as it applies on June 30, 1996.

Section.Text: All matters relating to the payment of premiums under the former Act shall be dealt with under that Act.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 78, the Commission’s estimate of the insurable earnings of all insured persons in the fiscal year 1996-97 shall be published in the Canada Gazette if it is not set out in the Main Estimates tabled in Parliament for that year.
The plan mentioned in section 79 shall be published in the Canada Gazette for the fiscal year 1996-97 if it is not included in the Main Estimates tabled in Parliament for that year.
The powers or functions of any person under the former Act shall be exercised or performed by the person who exercises the corresponding powers or performs the corresponding functions under this Act.

Boards of referees, panels, chairpersons, umpires and the chief umpire established, appointed or designated under the former Act continue as if they had been established, appointed or designated under this Act.

Section.Text: Waivers and agreements made under paragraph 4(1)(d) of the former Act and in effect when that Act is repealed continue in effect as though they had been made under paragraph 5(4)(d) of this Act.
The Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations providing for any other transitional matters, including regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: providing for the transition from weeks of insurable employment to hours of insurable employment, or from any other basis to another under Part VIII; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for establishing requirements to qualify to receive benefits, the duration of entitlement to benefits, benefit rates and disentitlement or disqualification from receiving benefits.

Section.Label: 168 to 186
Section.Text: [Amendments]
[Amendments]

Section.Label: 188 and 189
Section.Text: [Amendments]

Subsection.Text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, this Act comes into force on June 30, 1996.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Certain provisions in force on January 1, 1997
Subsection.Text: Section 4, subsection 5(6), sections 66 and 67, subsections 82(1) and (2), paragraphs 90(1)(d), (h) and (i), section 95 and subsections 96(4) and (5) come into force on January 1, 1997.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Certain provisions in force on January 5, 1997
Subsection.Text: The following provisions come into force on January 5, 1997:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the definitions major attachment claimant and minor attachment claimant in subsection 6(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: section 7;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 12(2);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: sections 14 to 17;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 19(2);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 28(4);

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: paragraph 30(1)(a) and subsections 30(5) and (6);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: paragraph 31(c);

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: paragraph 32(2)(c);

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 38(3);

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: section 55;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: paragraph 108(1)(h);

Paragraph.Label: (l.1)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 153.1(3); and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: Schedule I.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Certain provisions in force on January 5, 1997
Subsection.Text: Subsections 7.1(1) to (3) come into force on January 5, 1997, but in applying them the Commission may take into account notices issued under subsection 7.1(4) on or after June 30, 1996.

Subsection 19(3) comes into force on January 5, 1997, but the Commission may make deductions under subparagraph 19(3)(a)(i) on and after that date in respect of any failure to declare earnings for a period beginning on or after June 30, 1996.
The provisions set out in Schedule II apply in place of the provisions listed in subsections (2) and (3) from June 30, 1996 until the coming into force of those provisions.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Continuing application of benefit rate provision
Subsection.Text: The provisions enacted by section 6 of Schedule II continue to apply in place of sections 14, 16 and 17 of this Act to claimants whose benefit periods begin on or after June 30, 1996 and before January 5, 1997.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Certain provisions in force in January 1, 1998
Subsection.Text: Sections 172 to 175 come into force on January 1, 1998.

row.entry: Number of hours of insurable employment in qualifying period
6% and under
More than 6% but not more than 7%
More than 7% but not more than 8%

More than 9% but not more than 10%
More than 10% but not more than 11%
More than 11% but not more than 12%
More than 12% but not more than 13%
More than 13% but not more than 14%
More than 14% but not more than 15%
More than 15% but not more than 16%
More than 16%

Section.Text: The following applies in place of section 4:

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 17, subsection 82(2) and sections 95 and 145, the maximum yearly insurable earnings is $39,000 for 1996.
For the purposes of this Act, the maximum weekly insurable earnings is $750.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of subsection 5(6):

Subsection.Text: The Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations for excluding from insurable employment

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any employment if it appears to the Commission that because of the laws of a country other than Canada a duplication of contributions or benefits will result;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the entire employment of a person who is employed by one employer partly in insurable employment and partly in other employment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any employment if it appears to the Commission that the nature of the work performed by persons employed in that employment is similar to the nature of the work performed by persons employed in employment that is not insurable employment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the employment of a member of a religious order who has taken a vow of poverty and whose remuneration is paid directly or by the member to the order;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any employment in which persons are employed to an inconsiderable extent or for an inconsiderable consideration;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any employment provided under regulations made under section 24 or employment measures authorized by subsection 58(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any employment with an employer in which persons are employed for fewer than 20 hours in a week or in which the earnings of persons are less than 30% of the maximum weekly insurable earnings.

Section.Text: The following apply in place of the definitions major attachment claimant and minor attachment claimant in subsection 6(1):

Definition.Text: major attachment claimant means a claimant who qualifies to receive benefits and has been employed in insurable employment for 20 or more weeks in the claimant’s qualifying period; (prestataire de la première catégorie)

minor attachment claimant means a claimant who qualifies to receive benefits and has been employed in insurable employment for fewer than 20 weeks in the claimant’s qualifying period; (prestataire de la deuxième catégorie)

Section.Text: The following applies in place of section 7:

Subsection.Text: Unemployment benefits are payable as provided in this Part to an insured person who qualifies to receive them.
An insured person, other than a new entrant or a re-entrant to the labour force, qualifies if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has had an interruption of earnings from employment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has had during their qualifying period at least the number of weeks of insurable employment set out in the following table in relation to the regional rate of unemployment that applies to the person.

row.entry: Regional Rate of Unemployment
Required Number of Weeks of Insurable Employment
6% and under
more than 6% but not more than 7%
more than 7% but not more than 8%
more than 8% but not more than 9%
more than 9% but not more than 10%
more than 10% but not more than 11%
more than 11% but not more than 12%
more than 12% but not more than 13%
more than 13%

Subsection.MarginalNote: Qualification requirement for new entrants and re-entrants
Subsection.Text: An insured person who is a new entrant or a re-entrant to the labour force qualifies if the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has had an interruption of earnings from employment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has had 26 or more weeks of insurable employment during their qualifying period.

Subsection.Text: An insured person is a new entrant or a re-entrant to the labour force if, during the last 52 weeks before their qualifying period, the person has had fewer than 14

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: weeks of insurable employment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: weeks for which benefits have been paid or were payable to the person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: prescribed weeks that relate to employment in the labour force; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: weeks comprised of any combination of those weeks.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (4), a week that is taken into account under any of paragraphs (4)(a), (b) or (c) may not be taken into account under the other.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exhaustion or termination of entitlement to U.S. benefits
Subsection.Text: A claimant is not qualified to receive benefits if it is jointly determined that the claimant must first exhaust or terminate benefit rights under the laws of another jurisdiction, as provided by Article VI of the Agreement Between Canada and the United States Respecting Unemployment Insurance, signed on March 6 and 12, 1942.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of subsection 12(2):

Paragraph.Text: The maximum number of weeks for which benefits may be paid in a benefit period because of any reasons other than those referred to in subsection (3) shall be determined in accordance with the table in Schedule I by reference to the regional rate of unemployment that applies to the claimant and the number of weeks of insurable employment of the claimant in their qualifying period.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of section 14:

Subsection.Text: The rate of weekly benefits payable to a claimant is an amount calculated as follows, to a maximum of $413:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 55% of the claimant’s average weekly insurable earnings, in the case of a claimant in respect of whom paragraph (b) does not apply; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any case where it is established, in such manner as the Commission may direct, that the prescribed circumstances exist in relation to one or more persons who are dependants of the claimant or their spouse or that, in the opinion of the Commission, even though the prescribed circumstances do not exist, the claimant or their spouse supports one or more persons who are dependants of the claimant or of their spouse,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 60% of the claimant’s average weekly insurable earnings, if those earnings do not exceed 50% of the maximum weekly insurable earnings for the year in which the benefit period is established, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the greater of 55% of the claimant’s average weekly insurable earnings and $225, if the claimant’s average weekly insurable earnings exceed 50% of the maximum weekly insurable earnings for that year.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Average weekly insurable earnings — major attachment claimant
Subsection.Text: The average weekly insurable earnings of a major attachment claimant are the insurable earnings in the last 20 weeks of insurable employment in their qualifying period divided by 20.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Average weekly insurable earnings — minor attachment claimant
Subsection.Text: The average weekly insurable earnings of a minor attachment claimant are the insurable earnings in their qualifying period divided by the larger of the following divisors:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the divisor that equals the number of weeks of insurable employment in their qualifying period, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the divisor determined in accordance with the following table by reference to the applicable regional rate of unemployment.

row.entry: Regional Rate of Unemployment
Divisor
not more than 8%
more than 8% but not more than 9%
more than 9% but not more than 10%
more than 10% but not more than 11%
more than 11% but not more than 12%
more than 12% but not more than 13%
more than 13%

Subsection.Text: The Commission may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: defining and determining who is a dependant of a claimant or a spouse of a claimant, or who is a spouse of a claimant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: determining the weekly insurable earnings of claimants; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where earnings are paid or payable in the qualifying period for a period, whether on a weekly basis or otherwise, for calculating and establishing for the purposes of this Part

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the weeks or number of weeks that are to be taken as weeks of insurable employment in that period, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the amount to be taken as the insurable earnings or average weekly insurable earnings for any weeks or number of weeks in that period.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of subsection 19(2):

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (3) and (4), if a claimant has earnings during any other week of unemployment, there shall be deducted from the benefits payable to the claimant in that week the amount, if any, of the earnings that exceeds 25% of their weekly rate of benefit.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of subsection 28(4):

Paragraph.Text: No weeks of disqualification shall be carried forward against a claimant who has had 20 or more weeks of insurable employment since the event giving rise to the disqualification.

Subsection.Text: The following applies in place of paragraph 30(1)(a):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant has, since losing or leaving the employment, been employed in insurable employment for the number of weeks required by section 7 to qualify for benefits; or

Subsection.Text: The following applies in place of subsections 30(5) and (6):

Where a claimant who has lost or left an employment as described in subsection (1) makes an initial claim for benefits, the following weeks of insurable employment may not be used for the purposes of subsection 7(2) or (3):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: weeks of insurable employment from that or any other employment before the day on which that employment was lost or left; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: weeks of insurable employment in any employment that the claimant subsequently loses or leaves, as described in subsection (1).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Restriction on number of weeks and rate of benefits
Subsection.Text: No weeks of insurable employment in any employment that a claimant loses or leaves as described in subsection (1) may be used for the purposes of subsection 12(2) or section 14.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of paragraph 31(c):

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant, after the beginning of the period of suspension, accumulates with another employer the number of weeks of insurable employment required under section 7 in order to qualify to receive benefits under this Act.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of paragraph 32(2)(c):

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant, after the beginning of the period of leave, accumulates with another employer the number of weeks of insurable employment required under section 7 in order to qualify to receive benefits under this Act.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of section 66:
The premium rate for 1996 is the rate established for that year under section 48.1 of the Unemployment Insurance Act immediately before its repeal.
The following applies in place of section 67:

Subsection.Text: For every week during which a person is employed in insurable employment, the person shall pay, by deduction as provided in Part IV, an amount equal to such percentage of their insurable earnings as is fixed by the Commission as the employee’s premium for the year in which that week occurs.

For every week during which an employer employs a person in insurable employment, the employer shall pay, in respect of that person and in the manner provided in Part IV, an amount equal to such percentage of that person’s insurable earnings as is fixed by the Commission as the employer’s premium payable by employers or a class of employers of which the employer is a member, as the case may be, for the year in which that week occurs.

Notwithstanding subsections (1) and (2), where insurable earnings are paid to a person in a year after the year in which their insurable employment occurred, all that insurable employment is, for the purposes of calculating insurable earnings and premiums payable in respect of them, deemed to have occurred in the year in which the insurable earnings are paid.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of subsection 82(1):

Subsection.Text: Every employer paying remuneration to a person employed by the employer in insurable employment shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deduct the prescribed amount from that remuneration as or on account of the employee’s premium payable by that insured person under section 67 for any weeks in respect of which that remuneration is paid; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: remit that amount, together with the employer’s premium payable by the employer under that section for those weeks, to the Receiver General at the prescribed time and in the prescribed manner.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of section 95:

Subsection.Text: Where the aggregate of all amounts deducted as required from the insurable earnings of an insured person for a year, whether by one or more employers, on account of that person’s employee’s premiums for that year under this Act exceeds an amount equal to such percentage of the person’s maximum yearly insurable earnings for the year as is fixed by the Commission, the excess is an overpayment made by the person.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Limitation — remuneration for more than 52 weeks
Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding subsection (1) and section 3, an overpayment is not created when amounts are deducted and remitted as required from the insurable earnings of an insured person in excess of the percentage of the maximum yearly insurable earnings for the year, if the excess occurs by reason only that the remuneration paid to the person in that year is in respect of more than 52 calendar weeks.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of paragraph 108(1)(h):

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: for the allocation of the hours a person is employed with an employer and earnings to weeks or to pay periods;

Paragraph.Label: (h.1)
Paragraph.Text: for calculating and determining the hours a person is employed with an employer, the amount of insurable earnings of insured persons and the amount of premiums payable;

Paragraph.Label: (h.2)
Paragraph.Text: where earnings are paid or payable for a period otherwise than in respect of weeks, for calculating and establishing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the weeks or number of weeks to be taken as weeks of insurable employment in that period, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the amount to be taken as insurable earnings in any of those weeks or number of weeks in that period;

Section.Text: The following applies in place of subsection 153.1(3):

Paragraph.Text: The scheme established by the regulations may not provide special benefits to persons who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have less than 20 weeks of insurable employment in their qualifying period; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are subject to an increase under section 7.1 in the number of hours of insurable employment required to qualify for benefits.

Section.Text: The following applies in place of Schedule I:

row.entry: Number of Weeks of Insurable Employment
6% and under
More than 6% but not more than 7%
More than 7% but not more than 8%
More than 8% but not more than 9%
More than 9% but not more than 10%
More than 10% but not more than 11%
More than 11% but not more than 12%
More than 12% but not more than 13%
More than 13% but not more than 14%
More than 14% but not more than 15%
More than 15% but not more than 16%
More than 16%

Subsection.Text: Sections 15 to 20 and 22 apply to a claimant for any benefit period

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that begins on or after January 4, 2004; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that has not ended before January 4, 2004, but only for weeks of benefits that begin on or after that date.

Section.MarginalNote: Repeal of sections 127 and 128 of the Employment Insurance Act
Section.Text: The repeal of sections 127 and 128 of the Employment Insurance Act does not affect the validity of a disclosure of information, or an agreement for the purpose of making information available, made under those sections by the Minister of Human Resources Development or the Minister of State to be styled Minister of Human Resources and Skills Development.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) applies in respect of remittances by a prescribed person that are first due after February 25, 2008.
Subsection (2) applies in respect of payments and remittances that are required to be first made after February 25, 2008.

Section.Text: For the purposes of paragraph 4(a) of the Canada Employment Insurance Financing Board Act, the Board sets the premium rate under section 66 of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by section 127.

Subsection.Text: The maximum number of weeks for which benefits may be paid in a benefit period that is established for a claimant who is included in Pilot Project No. 10 and whose benefit period has not ended before the second Sunday before the day on which this Act receives royal assent is to be determined in accordance with Schedule I to the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by subsection 224(1).

Section.Text: Section 66.1 of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by section 9 of chapter 5 of the Statutes of Canada, 2001, is deemed to have read as follows:
Notwithstanding section 66, the premium rates for the years 2002 and 2003 are 2.2% and 2.1%, respectively.
Section 66.3 of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by section 25 of chapter 22 of the Statutes of Canada, 2004, is deemed to have read as follows:
Notwithstanding section 66, the premium rate for the year 2005 is 1.95%.

Subsection 224(1) applies with respect to every claimant whose benefit period has not ended before the day on which that subsection comes into force and whose benefit period does not begin after September 11, 2010.

With respect to a claimant to whom any of sections 3 to 6 applies whose benefit period has not been extended under any of subsections 10(13) to (13.3) of the Employment Insurance Act, subsection 55(10) of the Employment Insurance Regulations is deemed to read as follows:

Subsection.Text: In a claimant’s benefit period, a claimant who is not in Canada or a claimant referred to in subsection (8), subject to the applicable maximums set out in paragraphs (7)(a) and (b), may combine the weeks of benefits to which the claimant is entitled, but the total number of weeks of benefits shall not exceed 50 or, if the maximum number of weeks during which benefits may be paid to a claimant under section 225 of the Budget Implementation Act, 2009 is equal to or greater than 50 weeks as a result of the application of any provision of any Act of Parliament, other than the Employment Insurance Act, the number that corresponds to that maximum number of weeks.

Section.Text: Agreements referred to in subsection 152.02(1) of the Employment Insurance Act may be entered into at any time during the period that begins on the day on which this Act receives royal assent and ends on the day on which section 16 comes into force, but any such agreement that is entered into during that period is deemed to have been entered into on the day on which that section comes into force.

Despite paragraph 152.07(1)(a) of the Employment Insurance Act, a benefit period under Part VII.1 of that Act may begin on or after January 1, 2011 if the self-employed person to whom the benefit period relates has, during the period that begins on the later of the day on which this Act receives royal assent and January 1, 2010 and ends on April 1, 2010, entered into an agreement referred to in subsection 152.02(1) of that Act.

For the purpose of subsection 152.07(6) of the Employment Insurance Act, a violation accumulated by an individual under section 7.1 of that Act before the coming into force of that subsection is deemed to be a violation accumulated by the individual under section 152.07 on the day on which the notice of violation was given to the individual even though that section was not in force on that day.

Subsection.Text: Sections 2 and 3 apply to a claimant whose benefit period began less than 104 weeks before the day on which this Act comes into force if the period referred to in subsection 23(2) of the Employment Insurance Act

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has not ended before that day; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ended before that day and, within the period referred to in that subsection, the claimant’s parental leave is deferred or the claimant is directed to return to duty from parental leave in accordance with regulations made under the National Defence Act, and the claimant’s deferral or return to duty, as the case may be, has not ended before that day.

Subsection.Text: Section 2 applies to a claimant and the period referred to in subsection 23(2) of the Employment Insurance Act is extended to 104 weeks if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within the period referred to in that subsection, in accordance with regulations made under the National Defence Act, the claimant’s parental leave is deferred or the claimant is directed to return to duty from parental leave, as the case may be;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant’s deferral or return to duty ended before the day on which this Act comes into force;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant’s benefit period has not ended before that day; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the period referred to in that subsection ended before that day.

Subsection.Text: A claimant’s benefit period and the period referred to in subsection 23(2) of the Employment Insurance Act are each extended to 104 weeks if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within the period referred to in that subsection, in accordance with regulations made under the National Defence Act, the claimant’s parental leave is deferred or the claimant is directed to return to duty from parental leave, as the case may be;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant’s deferral or return to duty ended before the day on which this Act comes into force; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant’s benefit period and the period referred to in that subsection each began less than 104 weeks before that day and both ended before that day.

Section.Text: The account in the accounts of Canada known as the Employment Insurance Account is deemed to have been closed at the beginning of January 1, 2009 and removed from the accounts of Canada at that time.

For greater certainty, any amount purporting to have been credited to the Employment Insurance Account on or after January 1, 2009 and charged to the Consolidated Revenue Fund under section 76 of the Employment Insurance Act is deemed to have never been credited to that Account and charged to that Fund.

For greater certainty, all amounts credited or charged to the Employment Insurance Account on or after January 1, 2009 are deemed to have been credited or charged, as the case may be, to the Employment Insurance Operating Account established by section 70.2 of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by section 2185.

Every authority in any appropriation Act to make recoverable expenditures on behalf of the Employment Insurance Account in respect of the fiscal year 2010–2011 is deemed to be an authority to make recoverable expenditures on behalf of the Employment Insurance Operating Account established by section 70.2 of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by section 2185.

Section.MarginalNote: Employment Insurance Operating Account — audit for fiscal year 2008–2009
Section.Text: The Auditor General of Canada shall audit the Employment Insurance Operating Account, established by section 70.2 of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by section 2185, in respect of the fiscal year 2008–2009, and a report of that audit shall be made to the Minister of Human Resources and Skills Development.

Despite sections 2186 and 2195, and as a consequence of the establishment of the Employment Insurance Operating Account by section 70.2 of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by section 2185, the Auditor General of Canada may re-audit the Employment Insurance Account in respect of any fiscal year if he or she considers it necessary to do so, and a report of that audit is to be made to the Minister of Human Resources and Skills Development.
The following definitions apply in sections 252 to 270.

Definition.Text: board of referees means a board of referees established under Part VI of the Employment Insurance Act, as it read immediately before the coming into force of section 247. (conseil arbitral)

Pension Appeals Board means the Pension Appeals Board established under section 83 of the Canada Pension Plan, as it read immediately before the coming into force of section 229. (Commission d’appel des pensions)
Review Tribunal means a Review Tribunal established under section 82 of the Canada Pension Plan, as it read immediately before the coming into force of section 229. (tribunal de révision)
Social Security Tribunal means the Social Security Tribunal established under section 44 of the Department of Human Resources and Skills Development Act. (Tribunal de la sécurité sociale)
umpire means an umpire appointed under Part VI of the Employment Insurance Act, as it read immediately before the coming into force of section 247. (juge-arbitre)

Section.Text: The Pension Appeals Board, a Review Tribunal, a board of referees or an umpire must transfer to the Social Security Tribunal any information under their control that either relates to an application of which that Tribunal is seized or that the Governor in Council has, by regulation, prescribed.

Subsection.Text: The chairpersons of a board of referees referred to in subsection 265(1) continue to hold office until the earlier of the end of the term for which they were appointed and November 1, 2013.

Persons on panels referred to in subsection 111(3) of the Employment Insurance Act, as it read immediately before the coming into force of section 247, continue to hold office until the earlier of the end of the term for which they were appointed and November 1, 2013.

Despite the provisions of any contract, agreement or order, no person either appointed to hold office as chairperson of a board of referees or referred to in subsection (2) has any right to claim or receive any compensation, damages, indemnity or other form of relief from Her Majesty in right of Canada or from any employee or agent of Her Majesty for ceasing to hold that office or for the abolition of that office by the operation of this Division.
For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2), the Governor in Council may, by order, fix a day earlier than November 1, 2013.
Umpires continue to hold office until April 1, 2014.

Despite the provisions of any contract, agreement or order, no person appointed to hold office as umpire has any right to claim or receive any compensation, damages, indemnity or other form of relief from Her Majesty in right of Canada or from any employee or agent of Her Majesty for ceasing to hold that office or for the abolition of that office by the operation of this Division.

The board of referees remains seized of any appeal filed and not decided before April 1, 2013 under subsection 114(1) of the Employment Insurance Act, as it read immediately before the coming into force of section 247.
The board of referees must make its decision no later than October 31, 2013 or, if an order is made under subsection 263(4), the day before the day fixed by that order.

The General Division of the Social Security Tribunal becomes seized of any appeal referred to in subsection (1) if no decision has been made by the day referred to in subsection (2). The appeal is deemed to be an appeal filed with the General Division of the Social Security Tribunal on November 1, 2013 or, if an order is made under subsection 263(4), the day fixed by that order.
A person who is dissatisfied with a decision made under subsection (1) may appeal the decision to the Appeal Division of the Social Security Tribunal.

Section.Text: An appeal from a decision of a board of referees that could have been appealed to an umpire, but for the repeal of subsection 115(1) of the Employment Insurance Act by section 247, may be appealed to the Appeal Division of the Social Security Tribunal.

Subsection.Text: An umpire remains seized of any appeal filed and heard before April 1, 2013 under subsection 115(1) of the Employment Insurance Act, as it read immediately before the coming into force of section 247.
An umpire must make his or her decision no later than March 31, 2014.

The Appeal Division of the Social Security Tribunal becomes seized of any appeal referred to in subsection (1) if no decision has been made by the day referred to in subsection (2). The Appeal Division of the Social Security Tribunal is deemed to have granted leave to appeal on April 1, 2014.

Section.Text: The Appeal Division of the Social Security Tribunal is deemed to have granted leave to appeal on April 1, 2013 with respect to any appeal filed and not heard before April 1, 2013 under subsection 115(1) of the Employment Insurance Act, as it read immediately before the coming into force of section 247.

Subsection.Text: If no decision has been made before April 1, 2013 in respect of a request made under section 120 of the Employment Insurance Act as it read immediately before the coming into force of section 247, it is deemed to be an application made on April 1, 2013 under section 66 of the Department of Human Resources and Skills Development Act and is deemed to relate to a decision made, as the case may be, by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the General Division of the Social Security Tribunal, in the case of a decision made by a board of referees; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Appeal Division of the Social Security Tribunal, in the case of a decision made by an umpire.

Subsection.Text: An application made under section 66 of the Department of Human Resources and Skills Development Act after March 31, 2013 is deemed to relate to a decision made, as the case may be, by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the General Division of the Social Security Tribunal, in the case of a decision made by a board of referees; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Appeal Division of the Social Security Tribunal, in the case of a decision made by an umpire.

Section.Text: The provisions of the Employment Insurance Act repealed by this Act, and their related regulations, continue to apply to appeals of which the board of referees or an umpire remains seized under this Act, with any necessary adaptations.
Section 14 of the Employment Insurance Act, as amended by section 604, applies only to claimants whose benefit period is established on or after April 7, 2013.

Sections 18, 21 and 152.03 of the Employment Insurance Act, as amended by sections 15, 16 and 21, apply only to claims for benefits because of illness, injury or quarantine that are made for weeks that begin on or after the day on which sections 15, 16 and 21 come into force.
Sections 23.2 and 152.061 of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by sections 18 and 23, apply to a claimant for any benefit period

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that begins on or after the day on which sections 18 and 23 come into force; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that has not ended before that day, but only for weeks of benefits that begin on or after that day.

Section.Text: Any surplus of financial assets that remains after the satisfaction of the debts and liabilities of the Board on the day on which section 454 comes into force is to be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund and credited to the Employment Insurance Operating Account established under section 70.2 of the Employment Insurance Act.

Paragraphs 10(10)(a) and 152.11(11)(a) of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by sections 2 and 3, respectively, do not apply to the benefit period of a claimant or a self-employed person, as the case may be, in respect of any week for which the claimant or the self-employed person was confined in a jail, penitentiary or other similar institution before the coming into force of this Act.

Subsections 18(2) and 152.03(1.1) of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by sections 247 and 248, apply only to claims for benefits because of illness, injury or quarantine that are made for weeks that begin on or after the day on which sections 247 and 248 come into force.

Subsection.Text: If a period referred to in subsection 23.1(4) of the Employment Insurance Act, as it read immediately before January 3, 2016, has begun in respect of a claimant — as defined in subsection 2(1) of that Act — before that day but has not ended, then sections 12 and 23.1 of that Act, as they read on that day, apply to that claimant beginning on that day.

If a period referred to in subsection 152.06(3) of the Employment Insurance Act, as it read immediately before January 3, 2016, has begun in respect of a self-employed person — as defined in subsection 152.01(1) of that Act — before that day but has not ended, then sections 152.06 and 152.14 of that Act, as they read on that day, apply to that person beginning on that day.

Section.MarginalNote: Persons making initial claim for benefits
Section.Text: Paragraph 58(b) of the Employment Insurance Act, as it reads on the day on which this section comes into force, applies only to persons who make an initial claim for benefits, as defined in subsection 6(1) of that Act, on or after that day.

Subsection.Text: Subsections 23(1) and (2) of the Act are replaced by the following:
Notwithstanding section 18, but subject to this section, benefits are payable to a major attachment claimant to care for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one or more new-born children of the claimant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one or more children placed with the claimant for the purpose of adoption under the laws governing adoption in the province in which the claimant resides; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: one or more children if the claimant meets the requirements set out in the regulations made under paragraph 54(f.1).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Weeks for which benefits may be paid
Subsection.Text: Subject to section 12, benefits under this section are payable for each week of unemployment in the period that begins with the week in which

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the child or children of the claimant are born,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the child or children are actually placed with the claimant for the purpose of adoption, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the claimant first meets the requirements set out in the regulations made under paragraph 54(f.1)

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and ends 52 weeks after that week.

Subsection.Text: Section 23 of the Act is amended by adding the following after subsection (4.1):

Subsections 12(3) to (8) shall be read as including the situation where a claimant is caring for one or more children and meets the requirements set out in the regulations made under paragraph 54(f.1).

Section.Text: Section 54 of the Act is amended by adding the following after paragraph (f):

Paragraph.Label: (f.1)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of paragraphs 23(1)(c) and (2)(c) and subsection 23(5), respecting the following requirements, subject to consulting the governments of the provinces:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the circumstances in which the claimant must be caring for the child or children,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the criteria that the claimant must meet,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the conditions that the claimant must fulfil, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: any matter that the Commission considers necessary for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of section 23;

Section.Text: On the first day on which both section 10 of the Budget Implementation Act, 2000 has produced its effects and subsection 7(2) of this Act is in force, subsection 23(6) of the Employment Insurance Act, as enacted by that subsection 7(2), is renumbered as subsection (7) and is repositioned accordingly if required.

On the first day on which both subsection 107(3) of the Modernization of Benefits and Obligations Act and section 16 of this Act are in force, section 152.05 of the Employment Insurance Act is amended by adding the following after subsection (13):

Subsection.Text: Subsections 152.14(1) to (8) are to be read as including the situation where a self-employed person is caring for one or more children and meets the requirements set out in the regulations made under paragraph 54(f.1).

Section.Text: On the first day on which both section 109 of the Modernization of Benefits and Obligations Act and section 16 of this Act are in force:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: paragraph 54(f.1) of the Employment Insurance Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (f.1)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of paragraphs 23(1)(c) and (2)(c), subsection 23(5) paragraphs 152.05(1)(c) and (2)(c) and subsection 152.05(7), respecting the following requirements, subject to consulting the governments of the provinces:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the circumstances in which the claimant must be caring for the child or children,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the criteria that the claimant must meet,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the conditions that the claimant must fulfil, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: any other matter that the Commission considers necessary for the purpose of carrying out sections 23 and 152.05;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subsections 152.05(1) and (2) of the Employment Insurance Act are replaced by the following:

Subsection.Text: Subject to this Part, benefits are payable to a self-employed person to care for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one or more new-born children of the person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one or more children placed with the person for the purpose of adoption under the laws governing adoption in the province in which the person resides; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: one or more children if the self-employed person meets the requirements set out in the regulations made under paragraph 54(f.1).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Weeks for which benefits may be paid
Subsection.Text: Subject to section 152.14, benefits under this section are payable for each week of unemployment in the period

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that begins with the week in which the child or children of the self-employed person are born and that ends 52 weeks after that week;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that begins with the week in which the child or children of the self-employed person are actually placed with the self-employed person for the purpose of adoption and that ends 52 weeks after that week; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that begins with the week in which the self-employed person first meets the requirements set out in the regulations made under paragraph 54(f.1) and ends 52 weeks after that week.

Subsection.Text: Subsections 66(1.1) and (1.2) of the Act are repealed.
Subsection 66(7.1) of the Act is repealed.
